recordings.file-name: XC419317-1033 Trogon rufus(son in resp pl)EstVeracel_BA_050614_FIG.mp3
recordings.rmk: FCF01033 - Fonoteca Casa da Floresta

Comparison between songs of two Black-throated Trogons (e.g., 0:01, 0:03) and two Chestnut-backed Antbirds (0:12, 0:24). The song of the trogons is nasal, and the last element either does not slur or only slightly downslurs. The song of the antbirds is clear, and the last element obviously downslurs.

20 pairs of calls between two Black-throated Trogons. I watched the closer one throughout this episode, and it was a male, but I am not sure about the farther one. I did find a male about 2 minutes later where the farther one was singing, so it could have been a male, but its voice was higher than the first so I'm reluctant to say it was. I saw two males within about 4 m from one another in the same area only about 30 minutes before.

Male had been singing about 25 m away, but out of view due to vegetation. I played its song, and he flew in, landing about 7 m away,  on a perch about 4 m from the ground, in plain view. He sang long enough for me to make two recordings. Between the first and second recordings, the female flew in and perched about 2 m from the male. In this, the second recording, he flew away with his bursting flight call, initiated as he left the branch, flying almost directly overhead. I had to trim the recording at the end of its flight call because a woman laughed as the trogon flew overhead.

recordings.loc: Porto Alegre camp -- Biological Dynamics of Forest Fragments Project
recordings.rmk: This pair of T. rufus were recorded counter-singing, at close proximity to one another, from a primary forest plot at the BDFFP (reserve 3512). I estimated that both birds were ~2-3 m above ground-level. Aside from normalizing, the recording was unaltered. This recording is also archived at the Macaulay Library (ML243757091).

recordings.loc: Porto Alegre camp -- Biological Dynamics of Forest Fragments Project
recordings.rmk: This bird was recorded singing from a secondary forest plot (reserve 3015) at the BDFFP. Perhaps the clearest call, with the least insect obstruction, is at the 0:23 mark. It can also be heard giving its "chuckle" call after 0:28 when it briefly took flight. Aside from normalizing, the recording was unaltered. This recording is also archived at the Macaulay Library (ML243630011).
